--- Comment #2 from Michael Lydeamore (<mailto:michael.lydeamore@monash.edu|michael.lydeamore@monash.edu>) ---
Created attachment 3564
  --> <https://bugs.r-project.org/attachment.cgi?id=3564&action=edit>
Classed Errors for timeouts diffs

From the R Dev Day in November.

Thoughts are to use a hierarchical error system:

TimeoutError is the superclass that can be used more generally across the
broad.

The four errors currently thrown by R are considered TimeLimit*TimeoutErrors in
the patch. These are then broken down into CPU/non-CPU and session/non-session.

Some re-implementation of getCurrentCall() was needed to be able to return the
call back to the user.

Classed Errors for timeouts diffs

From the R Dev Day in November.

Thoughts are to use a hierarchical error system:

TimeoutError is the superclass that can be used more generally across the
broad.

The four errors currently thrown by R are considered TimeLimit*TimeoutErrors in
the patch. These are then broken down into CPU/non-CPU and session/non-session.

Some re-implementation of getCurrentCall() was needed to be able to return the
call back to the user.

text:
*[Bug 16256] bug in predict with type="terms" in the presence of missing*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=16256>

Osi Perrin Fisher (<mailto:osifisher@outlook.com|osifisher@outlook.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
                 CC|                            |osifisher@outlook.com

--- Comment #6 from Osi Perrin Fisher (<mailto:osifisher@outlook.com|osifisher@outlook.com>) ---
Created attachment 3565
  --> <https://bugs.r-project.org/attachment.cgi?id=3565&action=edit>
Adds the constant attribute back in when it's dropped by na.action being
"na.exclude"

<https://github.com/r-devel/r-dev-day/issues/138#issue-3635528249>

In stats:::naresid.exclude(), a matrix loses its "constant" attribute. This
patch stores that attribute in a variable before running the matrix through the
rest of the function, and reassigns it to the matrix just before the value is
returned. 

Credit to <https://github.com/adamwang15> for collaborating on this at R Dev Day
Melbourne 2025.

elements.text: [Bug 16256] bug in predict with type="terms" in the presence of missing

*[Bug 18969] New: Boxplot should only plot points when < 5 data points*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18969>

            Bug ID: 18969
           Summary: Boxplot should only plot points when < 5 data points
           Product: R
           Version: R-devel (trunk)
          Hardware: All
                OS: All
            Status: UNCONFIRMED
          Severity: minor
          Priority: P5
         Component: Graphics
          Assignee: R-core@R-project.org
          Reporter: alwang18@hotmail.com

Created attachment 3566
  --> <https://bugs.r-project.org/attachment.cgi?id=3566&action=edit>
Proposed solution

Currently boxplot() will create a boxplot even when there are fewer than 5
points, e.g.

```R
boxplot(c(1,2))
```

text:
*[Bug 18969] Boxplot should only plot points when < 5 data points*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18969>

--- Comment #1 from Alwin Wang (<mailto:alwang18@hotmail.com|alwang18@hotmail.com>) ---
This bug was discussed at the R Dev Day @ Australia 2025 here:
<https://github.com/r-devel/r-dev-day/issues/137> and SVN patch attached.

`boxplot.matrix()` and `boxplot.formula()` and boxplot call `boxplot.default()`
which then calls `bxp()`, `boxplot.stats()` and `fivenum()`.

The decision at R Dev Day was to leave `fivenum()` unchanged and modify
`boxplot.stats()` and `bxp()`.

- Return all NA for the stats and conf elements
- Return the data points as outliers in out instead, also updating group to
identify those "outliers" as belonging to the respective group
- For groups with NA stats, plot the outliers as points instead of a boxplot in
bxp()
- Tested with base R boxplot() and lattice::bwplot().

Running `make -i check` there is an error:

r-devel/src/library/grDevices/man/boxplot.stats.Rd#L111

```
Error: running examples in ‘grDevices-Ex.R’ failed
==> grDevices-Ex.Rout.fail <==
Warning in boxplot.stats(x) : Sample size is 4 which is less than 5.
+            m[n4 == 1, 3:4] == (3*nn[n4 == 1] + 1)/4,
+            m[,"lH"] == ( (nn+3) %/% 2) / 2,
+            m[,"uH"] == ((3*nn+2)%/% 2) / 2)
Error: m[n4 == 1, 1:2] == (nn[n4 == 1] + 3)/4 are not all TRUE
Execution halted
Error: testing 'grDevices' failed
```

Suggestions on how to modify grDevices-Ex.R would be much appreciated.

elements.text: [Bug 18969] Boxplot should only plot points when < 5 data points
